title: 112_hr2557
content: Establishment of a Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee. Establishment of a Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee within the Office of the Secretary of Health and Human Services to advise on interagency coordination, communication, and efforts to address tick-borne diseases. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee aims to minimize overlap in efforts, coordinate with other agencies, ensure interagency communication, represent diverse scientific viewpoints, and advise on priorities related to Lyme and tick-borne diseases. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, includes voting members from the scientific community to advise Federal agencies on priorities related to Lyme and tick-borne diseases. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, includes members from the scientific community, tick-borne disease voluntary organizations, and health care providers with relevant experience. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, includes members with relevant experience in treating a broad range of tick-borne diseases, patient representatives, and representatives from State and local health departments and organizations. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes members representing diverse scientific perspectives relevant to their duties, as well as nonvoting ex officio members from various Federal agencies overseeing tick-borne disease activities. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes nonvoting, ex officio members from Federal agencies overseeing tick-borne disease activities, such as the CDC, NIH, FDA, and others as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary designates co-chairpersons for the Committee. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee includes additional Federal agencies as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary designates the Assistant Secretary for Health as the co-chairperson, and the appointed members elect a public co-chairperson for a 2-year term. Each member serves a 4-year term, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee members serve 4-year terms and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members may serve after their terms expire until successors take office. The Committee holds public meetings at least twice a year, with additional meetings as needed. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee holds public meetings at least twice a year, with additional meetings as needed. Meetings are conducted as required by law and regulations, and a report must be submitted annually. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee must submit an annual report to the Secretary, including a description of its functions, list of members and their affiliations, and a summary of activities and recommendations from the previous year. Authorization of Appropriations: $250,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 to carry out the Act. These funds will cover expenses and per diem costs for the Committee under the Federal Advisory Committee Act, with the stipulation that no voting member can be a permanent salaried employee.
